* [တႆး](https://shn.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E1%81%B6%E1%80%AF%E1%81%BC%E1%80%BA%E1%80%95%E1%80%BD%E1%80%84%E1%80%BA%E1%80%9D%E1%80%B5%E1%80%84%E1%80%BA%E1%80%B8 "ၶုၼ်ပွင်ဝဵင်း – Shan")
* [తెలుగు](https://te.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E0%B0%AE%E0%B1%87%E0%B0%AF%E0%B0%B0%E0%B1%8D "మేయర్ – Telugu")

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Head of municipal government such as a town or city

For other uses, see [Mayor (disambiguation)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor_(disambiguation) "Mayor (disambiguation)").

Not to be confused with [Major](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Major "Major").

In many countries, a **mayor** is the highest-ranking [official](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Official "Official") in a [municipal government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Municipal_corporation "Municipal corporation") such as that of a [city](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/City "City") or a [town](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Town "Town"). Worldwide, there is a wide [variance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Variance "Variance") in local laws and customs regarding the powers and responsibilities of a mayor as well as the means by which a mayor is elected or otherwise mandated. Depending on the system chosen, a mayor may be the chief executive officer of the municipal government, may simply chair a multi-member governing body with little or no independent power, or may play a solely ceremonial role. A mayor's duties and responsibilities may be to appoint and oversee municipal managers and employees, provide basic governmental services to constituents, and execute the laws and ordinances passed by a municipal governing body (or mandated by a state, territorial or national governing
body). Options for selection of a mayor include direct election by the public, or selection by an elected governing council or board.

The term *mayor* shares a linguistic origin with the military rank of *[major](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Major_(rank) "Major (rank)")*, both ultimately derived from French *majeur*, which in turn derives from Latin *maior*, the comparative form of the adjective *magnus*.

History
-------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: History")]

### United Kingdom

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: United Kingdom")]

Further information: [Mayors in England](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayors_in_England "Mayors in England") and [Mayors in Wales](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayors_in_Wales "Mayors in Wales")

In modern England and Wales, the position of mayor descends from the feudal lord's [bailiff](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bailiff "Bailiff") or [reeve](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reeve_(England) "Reeve (England)") (*see [borough](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Borough "Borough")*). The [chief magistrate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_magistrate "Chief magistrate") of [London](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London "London") bore the title of [portreeve](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portreeve "Portreeve") for considerably more than a century after the [Norman Conquest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norman_Conquest "Norman Conquest"). This official was elected by popular choice, a privilege secured from [King John](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John,_King_of_England "John, King of England"). By the beginning of the 12th century, the title of portreeve gave way to that of mayor as the designation of the chief officer of London, followed around 1190 by that of [Winchester](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Winchester "Winchester"). Other boroughs adopted the title later.[*[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*]

In the 19th century, the [Municipal Corporations Act 1882](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Municipal_Corporations_Act_1882 "Municipal Corporations Act 1882"), Section 15, regulated the election of mayors. The mayor was to be a fit person elected annually on 9 November by the council of the borough from among the aldermen or councilors or persons qualified to be such. His term of office was one year, but he was eligible for re-election. He might appoint a deputy to act during illness or absence, and such deputy must be either an alderman or councilor. A mayor who was absent from the borough for more than two months became disqualified and had to vacate his office. A mayor was *ex officio* a [justice of the peace](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Justice_of_the_peace "Justice of the peace") for the borough during his year of office and the following year. He received such remuneration as the council thought reasonable. These provisions have now been repealed.

In medieval Wales, the [Laws of Hywel Dda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laws_of_Hywel_Dda "Laws of Hywel Dda") codified the mayor ([Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medieval_Latin "Medieval Latin"): **maior**; [Welsh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Welsh_language "Welsh language"): **maer**) as a position at the [royal courts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Welsh_kingdoms "Welsh kingdoms") charged with administering the serfs of the [king's lands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demesne "Demesne"). To maintain its dependence on and loyalty to the Crown, the position was forbidden to the leaders of the clan groups.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor#cite_note-HyDda-1) A separate mayor, known as the "cow dung mayor" (*maer biswail*), was charged with overseeing the royal cattle.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor#cite_note-HyDda-1) There were similar offices at the Scottish and Irish courts.[*[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*]

The office of [mayor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayors_and_provosts_in_the_United_Kingdom "Mayors and provosts in the United Kingdom") in most modern English and Welsh boroughs and towns did not in the 20th century entail any important administrative duties and was generally regarded as an honor conferred for local distinction, long service on the council, or for past services. The mayor was expected to devote much of their time to civic, ceremonial, and representational functions, and to preside over meetings for the advancement of the public welfare. The administrative duties of mayors were to act as returning officer at parliamentary elections and to chair the meetings of the council.

The mayor of a [town council](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Town_council "Town council") is officially known as "town mayor" (although in popular parlance, the word *town* is often dropped). The person is known as "mayor" regardless of gender; the wife of a male mayor is traditionally known as the "mayoress". Since the [1974 local government reforms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_Government_Act_1972 "Local Government Act 1972"), mayors are also appointed to English [local government districts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_government_districts "Local government districts") which have [borough status](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Borough_status_in_the_United_Kingdom "Borough status in the United Kingdom"). This results in mayors of districts which include towns which also have separate mayors. In districts which do not have borough status, the role of civic leader is taken by the chairman of the council, who undertakes exactly the same functions as a mayor of a district with borough status.

Many major cities in the [United Kingdom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom") and throughout the [Commonwealth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations "Commonwealth of Nations") have a [lord mayor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lord_mayor "Lord mayor"), a special recognition bestowed by the [sovereign](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monarchy_of_the_United_Kingdom "Monarchy of the United Kingdom"). Although the position is often ceremonial, with executive responsibilities under the control of an elected mayor, lord mayors in several Commonwealth cities including [Belfast](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belfast "Belfast"), [Cardiff](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cardiff "Cardiff"), [Brisbane](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brisbane "Brisbane"), and [Dublin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dublin "Dublin") hold both ceremonial and executive duties. Some lord mayors, including the [Lord Mayor of Sydney (Australia)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_mayors,_lord_mayors_and_administrators_of_Sydney "List of mayors, lord mayors and administrators of Sydney"), are elected.[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor#cite_note-2)

In [Scotland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scotland "Scotland") the post holders are known as convenors, [provosts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Provost_(civil) "Provost (civil)"), or lord provosts depending on the local authority.

#### Directly elected mayors

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Directly elected mayors")]

Main article: [Directly elected mayors in England](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Directly_elected_mayors_in_England "Directly elected mayors in England")

Since [reforms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_Government_Act_2000 "Local Government Act 2000") introduced in 2000, a number of English local authorities have [directly elected mayors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elected_mayors_in_the_United_Kingdom "Elected mayors in the United Kingdom") who combine the "civic" mayor role with that of [leader of the council](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leader_of_the_council "Leader of the council") and have greater powers than either.[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor#cite_note-3) Areas which now have directly elected mayors include cities, local government districts which cover several towns and rural areas.

In 2014 [combined authority](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Combined_authority "Combined authority") areas where created which, similarly to the [Greater London Authority](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greater_London_Authority "Greater London Authority"), include two or more local authority districts. the Mayors (Also known as Metro Mayors or Regional Mayors) who lead these authority areas, have much more expansive [devolved](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Devolution_in_the_United_Kingdom "Devolution in the United Kingdom") governmental powers compared to their local council counterparts who do not, and have responsibility for larger geographical areas that can include multiple cities and towns. These regional mayors have a much larger political significance and are seen as the chief representative for their region, they sit on the [Mayoral Council for England](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayoral_Council_for_England "Mayoral Council for England") and, the [Council of the Nations and Regions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Council_of_the_Nations_and_Regions "Council of the Nations and Regions") where they sit alongside leaders from the UK Government and Devolved Governments of Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.

### Continental Europe

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Continental Europe")]

See also: [Mayor of the palace](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor_of_the_palace "Mayor of the palace") and [Podestà](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Podest%C3%A0 "Podestà")

The original [Frankish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franks "Franks") mayors or majordomos were – like the Welsh *meiri* – lords commanding the king's lands around the [Merovingian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Merovingians "Merovingians") courts in [Austrasia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Austrasia "Austrasia"), [Burgundy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingdom_of_Burgundy "Kingdom of Burgundy"), and [Neustria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neustria "Neustria"). The mayorship of Paris eventually became hereditary in the [Pippinids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pippinids "Pippinids"), who later established the [Carolingian dynasty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carolingian_dynasty "Carolingian dynasty").

In modern [France](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/France "France"), since the [Revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_Revolution "French Revolution"), a mayor (*maire*) and a number of mayoral adjuncts (*adjoints au maire*) are selected by the municipal council from among their number. Most of the administrative work is left in their hands, with the full council meeting comparatively infrequently. The model was copied throughout Europe in Britain's mayors, Italy's [sindacos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sindaco "Sindaco"), most of the German states' [burgomasters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burgomaster "Burgomaster"), and Portugal's [presidents of the municipal chambers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_the_Municipal_Chamber "President of the Municipal Chamber").

In [Medieval Italy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medieval_Italy "Medieval Italy"), the [city-states](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_city-states "Italian city-states") who did not consider themselves independent principalities or dukedoms – particularly those of the Imperial [Ghibelline](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ghibelline "Ghibelline") faction – were led by [podestàs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Podest%C3%A0 "Podestà").

The [Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greece "Greece") equivalent of a mayor is the [demarch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demarch "Demarch") ([Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language"): δήμαρχος, [lit.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Literal_translation "Literal translation") '[archon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Archon "Archon") of the [deme](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deme "Deme")').

#### Scandinavia

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Scandinavia")]

In [Denmark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denmark "Denmark") all [municipalities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Municipalities_of_Denmark "Municipalities of Denmark") are led by a political official called *[borgmester](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burgomaster "Burgomaster")*, 'mayor'. The mayor of [Copenhagen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Copenhagen "Copenhagen") is however called *[overborgmester](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_mayors_of_Copenhagen "List of mayors of Copenhagen")* 'lord mayor'. In that city other mayors, *borgmestre* (plural), are subordinate to the lord mayor with different undertakings, like ministers to a prime minister. In other municipalities in Denmark there is only a single mayor.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/1389-09-04%2C_brev_Iserlohn.jpg/250px-1389-09-04%2C_brev_Iserlohn.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:1389-09-04,_brev_Iserlohn.jpg)

Document of 1389 on the election of the [Mayor of Stockholm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor_of_Stockholm "Mayor of Stockholm")

In [Norway](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norway "Norway") and [Sweden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sweden "Sweden") the mayoral title *borgermester**/**borgmästare* has now been abolished. Norway abolished it in 1937 as a title of the non-political top manager of (city) municipalities and replaced it with the title *rådmann* ('[alderman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alderman "Alderman")' or '[magistrate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magistrate "Magistrate")'), which is still in use when referring to the top managers of the [municipalities of Norway](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Municipalities_of_Norway "Municipalities of Norway"). The top *elected* official of the municipalities of Norway, on the other hand, has the title *ordfører*, which actually means 'word-bearer', i.e. 'chairperson' or 'president', an equivalent to the Swedish word *[ordförande](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ordf%C3%B6rande "wikt:ordförande")*.

In [Sweden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sweden "Sweden") *borgmästare* was a title of the senior judge of the courts of the cities, courts which were called *rådhusrätt*, literally 'town hall court', somewhat of an equivalent to an English [magistrates' court](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magistrates%27_court_(England_and_Wales) "Magistrates' court (England and Wales)"). These courts were abolished in 1971. Until 1965, these mayor judges on historical grounds also performed some administrative functions in the board of magistrates, in Swedish known collectively as *magistrat*. Until 1965 there were also municipal mayors (*kommunalborgmästare*), who had these non-political administrative roles in smaller cities without a magistrates' court or *magistrat*. This office was an invention of the 20th century as the smaller cities in Sweden during the first half of the 20th century subsequently lost their own courts and magistrates.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Arthur-Castren.jpg/250px-Arthur-Castren.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Arthur-Castren.jpg)

[Arthur Castrén](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arthur_Castr%C3%A9n "Arthur Castrén") (1866–1946), the [Mayor of Helsinki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor_of_Helsinki "Mayor of Helsinki"), in the 1930s

In the 16th century in Sweden, king [Gustav Vasa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gustav_Vasa "Gustav Vasa") considerably centralised government and appointed the mayors directly. In 1693 king [Charles XI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_XI "Charles XI") accepted a compromise after repeated petitions from the Estate of the Burgesses over decades against the royal mayor appointments. The compromise was that the burgesses in a city could normally nominate a mayor under the supervision of the local governor. The nominee was then to be presented to and appointed by the king, but the king could appoint mayors directly in exceptional cases. This was codified in the [Instrument of Government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Instrument_of_Government "Instrument of Government") of 1720 and on 8 July the same year [Riksrådet ("the Council of the Realm")](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Privy_Council_of_Sweden "Privy Council of Sweden") decided, after a petition from the said Estate, that only the city could present nominees, not the king or anyone else. Thus the supervision of the local governor and directly appointed mayors by the king ceased after 1720 (the so-called [Age of Liberty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Age_of_Liberty "Age of Liberty")). On 16 October 1723, it was decided after a petition that the city should present three nominees, of whom the king (or the Council of the Realm) appointed one.[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor#cite_note-NF-4) This was kept as a rule from then on in all later regulations[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor#cite_note-NF-4) and was also kept as a tradition in the [1809 Instrument of Government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Instrument_of_Government_(1809) "Instrument of Government (1809)") ([§ 31](https://sv.wikisource.org/wiki/Regeringsform_1809#.C2.A731.)) until 1965.

In [Finland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Finland "Finland"), there are two mayors, in [Tampere](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tampere "Tampere") and [Pirkkala](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pirkkala "Pirkkala"). Usually in Finland the highest executive official is not democratically elected, but is appointed to a public office by the city council, and is called simply *kaupunginjohtaja* 'city manager' or *kunnanjohtaja* 'municipal manager', depending on whether the municipality defines itself as a city. The term *pormestari* 'mayor', from Swedish *borgmästare* confusingly on historical grounds has referred to the highest official in the registry office and in the city courts (abolished in 1993) as in Sweden, not the city manager. In addition, *pormestari* is also an honorary title, which may be given for distinguished service in the post of the city manager. The city manager of Helsinki is called *ylipormestari*, which translates to 'chief mayor', for historical reasons. Furthermore, the term *city manager* may be seen translated as *mayor*.

#### Spain

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Spain")]

The office of the *[Alcalde](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alcalde "Alcalde")* evolved during the [Reconquista](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reconquista "Reconquista") as new lands were settled by the expanding kingdoms of [León](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingdom_of_Le%C3%B3n "Kingdom of León") and [Castile](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingdom_of_Castile "Kingdom of Castile"). As fortified settlements in the area between the [Douro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Douro "Douro") and [Tagus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tagus "Tagus") rivers became true urban centers, they gained, from their [feudal lords](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feudalism "Feudalism") or the kings of Leon and Castile, the right to have councils. Among the rights that these councils had was to elect a municipal judge (*iudex* in [Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medieval_Latin "Medieval Latin") and *juez* in Spanish). These judges were assisted in their duties by various assistant judges, called *alcaldes*, whose number depended on the number of parishes the town had.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor#cite_note-5) The title *alcalde* was [borrowed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loanword "Loanword") from the Arabic *[al-qaḍi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qadi "Qadi")* (قاضي), meaning 'the judge'.[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor#cite_note-6)

The word *alcalde* originally was used for simple judges, as in [Andalusian Arabic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andalusian_Arabic "Andalusian Arabic"). Only later was it applied to the presiding municipal magistrate.[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor#cite_note-7) This early use continued to be reflected in its other uses, such as *alcaldes del crimen*, the judges in the *[audiencias](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Audiencia_Real "Audiencia Real")*; *Alcaldes de la Casa y Corte de Su Majestad*, who formed the highest tribunal in Castile and also managed the royal court; *alcaldes mayores*, a synonym for [*corregidor*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corregidor_(position) "Corregidor (position)"); and *alcaldes de barrio*, who were roughly the equivalent of British [parish constables](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parish_constable "Parish constable"). Because of this, the municipal *alcalde* was often referred to as an *alcalde ordinario*.

Mayors by country
-----------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Mayors by country")]

### Armenia

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Armenia")]

See also: [Mayor of Yerevan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor_of_Yerevan "Mayor of Yerevan")

Mayors in [Armenia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Armenia "Armenia") are the head of the executive branch of [municipal government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Municipalities_of_Armenia "Municipalities of Armenia"). Mayors are often elected by the respective city council and serve for a five-year term. The mayor heads the community administration, nominates members of the administration to various posts, and oversees the municipal budget.[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor#cite_note-8)

### Australia

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Australia")]

In Australian councils, the mayor is generally the member of the council who acts as a ceremonial figurehead at official functions, as well as carrying the authority of the council between meetings. Mayoral decisions made between meetings are subject to council and may be confirmed or repealed if necessary. Mayors in Australia may be elected either directly through a ballot for the position of mayor at a local-government election, or alternatively may be elected from within the council at a meeting.

The civic regalia and insignia of local government have basically remained unaltered for centuries. For ceremonial occasions a mayor may wear robes, a [mayoral chain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Livery_collar "Livery collar") and a [mace](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ceremonial_mace "Ceremonial mace"). Mayors have the title of *[His/Her Worship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Worship_(style) "Worship (style)")* whilst holding the position.

In councils where [councillors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Councillors "Councillors") are elected representing political parties, the mayor is normally the leader of the party receiving the most seats on council. In [Queensland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Queensland "Queensland"), the [lord mayor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lord_mayor "Lord mayor") and mayors are elected by popular vote at the general council election.

### Bangladesh

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Bangladesh")]

See also: [List of city corporations in Bangladesh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_city_corporations_in_Bangladesh "List of city corporations in Bangladesh")

Mayors in [Bangladesh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bangladesh "Bangladesh") are elected every five years. They are very powerful in municipal government. The mayor is the highest-ranking official in municipal governments in Bangladesh.

### Brazil

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Brazil")]

Every municipality in Brazil elects a mayor (Portuguese: *prefeito/prefeita*) and a vice-mayor (Portuguese: *vice-prefeito/vice-prefeita*) for a four-year term, acting as an executive officer with the city council (Portuguese: *Câmara Municipal*) functioning with legislative powers. The mayor can be re-elected and manage the city for two consecutive terms.[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor#cite_note-auto-9)

Mayoral elections in Brazil occur in two different ways: in municipalities with more than 200,000 inhabitants, the voting happens in a [two-round system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two-round_system "Two-round system"), like the [presidential](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Presidential_elections_in_Brazil "Presidential elections in Brazil") and [gubernatorial](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federative_units_of_Brazil "Federative units of Brazil") elections. In municipalities with less than 200,000 inhabitants, the voting happens in a [relative majority system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plurality_(voting) "Plurality (voting)") (with only one round).[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor#cite_note-auto-9)[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor#cite_note-10)[[11]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor#cite_note-11)[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor#cite_note-12)

The Brazilian system works similarly to the [mayor-council government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor-council_government "Mayor-council government") in the United States.

### Canada

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Canada")]

See also: [Local government in Canada](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_government_in_Canada "Local government in Canada") and [Municipal elections in Canada](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Municipal_elections_in_Canada "Municipal elections in Canada")

The chief executives of [boroughs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Borough#Canada "Borough") (*[arrondissements](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arrondissement#Quebec "Arrondissement")*) in [Quebec](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quebec "Quebec") are termed mayors (*maires/mairesses* in French). A borough mayor simultaneously serves as head of the borough council and as a regular councillor on the main city council. The scheduling of municipal elections in Canada varies by jurisdiction, as each province and territory has its own laws regarding municipal governance.

As is the practice in most Commonwealth countries, in Canada a mayor is addressed as His/Her Worship while holding office.

#### Reeve

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: Reeve")]

In a few [municipalities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_municipalities_in_Ontario "List of municipalities in Ontario") and [townships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Township "Township") in [Ontario](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ontario "Ontario"), the **reeve** is the elected head of the municipality, and the second-in-command is referred to as the **deputy reeve**. Historically, in some small [townships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Township_(Canada) "Township (Canada)"), the title *reeve* was used instead of mayor. In some other municipalities, *mayor* and *reeve* were two separate offices, with the mayor retaining leadership powers while the reeve was equivalent to what other municipalities called an *[at-large](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/At-large "At-large") councillor*. Today most municipalities in the province now designate their elected municipal government heads as mayors, but a small handful retain the position. This continues to be the case in the following municipalities and [townships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Township "Township"):

* [Howick Township](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Howick,_Ontario "Howick, Ontario"), [Huron County](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Huron_County,_Ontario "Huron County, Ontario")
* [North Huron Township](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Huron,_Ontario "North Huron, Ontario"), [Huron County](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Huron_County,_Ontario "Huron County, Ontario")
* [Beckwith Township](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beckwith,_Ontario "Beckwith, Ontario"), [Lanark County](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lanark_County "Lanark County")
* [Drummond/North Elmsley Township](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drummond/North_Elmsley "Drummond/North Elmsley"), [Lanark County](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lanark_County "Lanark County")
* [Lanark Highlands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lanark_Highlands "Lanark Highlands"), [Lanark County](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lanark_County "Lanark County")
* [Montague Township](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Montague,_Ontario "Montague, Ontario"), [Lanark County](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lanark_County "Lanark County")
* [Tay Valley Township](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tay_Valley "Tay Valley"), [Lanark County](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lanark_County "Lanark County")
* [Township of The Archipelago](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Archipelago "The Archipelago"), [Parry Sound District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parry_Sound_District "Parry Sound District")
* [Alberton Township](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alberton,_Ontario "Alberton, Ontario"), [Rainy River District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rainy_River_District "Rainy River District")
* [Chapple Township](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chapple,_Ontario "Chapple, Ontario"), [Rainy River District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rainy_River_District "Rainy River District")
* [La Vallee Township](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/La_Vallee,_Ontario "La Vallee, Ontario"), [Rainy River District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rainy_River_District "Rainy River District")
* [Morley Township](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morley,_Ontario "Morley, Ontario"), [Rainy River District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rainy_River_District "Rainy River District")
* [Dorion Township](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dorion,_Ontario "Dorion, Ontario"), [Thunder Bay District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thunder_Bay_District "Thunder Bay District")
* [Gilles Township](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gillies,_Ontario "Gillies, Ontario"), [Thunder Bay District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thunder_Bay_District "Thunder Bay District")
* [Brethour Township](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brethour "Brethour"), [Timiskaming District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timiskaming_District "Timiskaming District")
* [Casey Township](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Casey,_Ontario "Casey, Ontario"), [Timiskaming District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timiskaming_District "Timiskaming District")
* [Chamberlain Township](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chamberlain,_Ontario "Chamberlain, Ontario"), [Timiskaming District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timiskaming_District "Timiskaming District")
* [Municipality of Charlton and Dack](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charlton_and_Dack "Charlton and Dack"), [Timiskaming District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timiskaming_District "Timiskaming District")
* [Evaturel Township](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evanturel "Evanturel"), [Timiskaming District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timiskaming_District "Timiskaming District")
* [Gauthier Township](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gauthier,_Ontario "Gauthier, Ontario"), [Timiskaming District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timiskaming_District "Timiskaming District")
* [Harley Township](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harley,_Ontario "Harley, Ontario"), [Timiskaming District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timiskaming_District "Timiskaming District")
* [Harris Township](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harris,_Ontario "Harris, Ontario"), [Timiskaming District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timiskaming_District "Timiskaming District")
* [Hilliard Township](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hilliard,_Ontario "Hilliard, Ontario"), [Timiskaming District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timiskaming_District "Timiskaming District")
* [Hudson Township](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hudson,_Ontario "Hudson, Ontario"), [Timiskaming District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timiskaming_District "Timiskaming District")
* [James Township](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James,_Ontario "James, Ontario"), [Timiskaming District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timiskaming_District "Timiskaming District")
* [Kerns Township](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerns,_Ontario "Kerns, Ontario"), [Timiskaming District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timiskaming_District "Timiskaming District")
* [Village of Thornloe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thornloe,_Ontario "Thornloe, Ontario"), [Timiskaming District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timiskaming_District "Timiskaming District")

The reeve is also the chief elected official in most of [Alberta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alberta "Alberta")'s [municipal districts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_municipal_districts_in_Alberta "List of municipal districts in Alberta").

The elected heads of rural municipalities (RM) in the provinces of [Manitoba](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manitoba "Manitoba") and [Saskatchewan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saskatchewan "Saskatchewan") are usually referred to as a reeve.

### Dominican Republic

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Dominican Republic")]

The mayor of a municipality in the [Dominican Republic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dominican_Republic "Dominican Republic") is called indistinctly *alcalde* or *síndico*. The latter name is preferred to avoid confusing the title with the similar-sounding *alcaide* (lit. '[prison warden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prison_warden "Prison warden")'). Such a person is the governor of the municipality whose township elected him (or her) by [direct vote](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Direct_vote "Direct vote") for a term of four years. The daily duties of the mayor's office are restricted to local governance, and as such, it is responsible for the coordination of [waste collection](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waste_collection "Waste collection"), [upkeep](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maintenance,_repair,_and_operations "Maintenance, repair, and operations") of [public spaces](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_spaces "Public spaces") (e.g., parks, undeveloped urban parcels, streets), traffic light control, sewage, and most public utilities. In practice, most of its duties are centered on minor street repairs (new or large road projects, like overpasses, bridges, pedestrian crossings, etc. are handled by the Ministry of Public Works (Spanish: *Ministerio de Obras Públicas*), under the direct control of the central government. Subcontracting [garbage collection](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waste_collection "Waste collection") and management, overseeing the use of public spaces, and arbitrating neighborhood land use disputes, which are managed by the National Property office (Spanish: *Oficina de Bienes Nacionales*), is also controlled by the mayor's office. Water, electrical supply and public transportation coordination are handled by several central government offices, and as such, are not under the control of the mayor.

### France

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: France")]

Main article: [Mayor (France)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor_(France) "Mayor (France)")

Mayors (*maires*) are elected for a six-year term by the municipal council, whose members are elected by direct universal suffrage in [local elections](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elections_in_France#Municipal "Elections in France") held every six years.

### Germany

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Germany")]

In Germany, local government is regulated by [state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/States_of_Germany "States of Germany") statutes. Nowadays only the mayors of the three city-states (Berlin, Hamburg and [Bremen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bremen_(state) "Bremen (state)")) are still elected by the respective city-state parliaments. In all the other states the mayors are now elected directly by the [EU citizens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/EU_citizen "EU citizen") living in that area. The post of mayor may be said to be a professional one, the mayor being the head of the local government, and requiring, in order to be eligible, training in administration. In big cities (details are regulated by state statutes) the official title is ***Oberbürgermeister*** (mayor). In these cities, a "simple" mayor is just a deputy responsible for a distinct task (e.g., welfare or construction works). Big cities are usually *[kreisfrei](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kreisfreie_Stadt "Kreisfreie Stadt")* ('district-free'). That means that the city council also has the powers and duties of a rural district council. The leader of a rural district council is called *Landrat* ('land counsellor'). In that case, the chief mayor also has the duties and powers of a *Landrat*.

There are also some German states that allow smaller cities to have an *Oberbürgermeister* as well. In [Saarland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saarland "Saarland"), for instance, every city with more than 35,000 inhabitants has one, and in [Saxony-Anhalt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saxony-Anhalt "Saxony-Anhalt") every city with a population bigger than 25,000 has one. The term *Oberbürgermeister* is not used in the three city-states, where the mayors are simultaneously [head of state governments](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minister-president "Minister-president"), but *Regierender Bürgermeister* ([Governing Mayor of Berlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Governing_Mayor_of_Berlin "Governing Mayor of Berlin")), *Erster Bürgermeister* ([First Mayor of the city-state of Hamburg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Mayor_of_the_city-state_of_Hamburg "First Mayor of the city-state of Hamburg")) and *Präsident des Senats und Bürgermeister* ([President of the Senate and Mayor of Bremen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor_of_Bremen "Mayor of Bremen")) are used. However, the term *Oberbürgermeister* was used for the head of the state government of [West Berlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Berlin "West Berlin") until 1951 and was also used in [East Berlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Berlin "East Berlin") from 1948 to January 1991.

### Greece

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: Greece")]

See also: [Mayor of Athens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor_of_Athens "Mayor of Athens") and [Mayor of Thessaloniki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor_of_Thessaloniki "Mayor of Thessaloniki")

Mayors (δήμαρχοι, *dēmarchoi*, sing. δήμαρχος, *[dēmarchos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demarchos "Demarchos")*) in [Greece](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greece "Greece") were previously elected every four years in [local elections](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elections_in_Greece#Local_elections "Elections in Greece") and are the head of various municipal governments in which the state is divided. Starting in 2014, mayors are elected for a five-year term. Local administration elections for the new, consolidated municipalities and peripheries will henceforth be held together with the [elections](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elections_in_the_European_Union "Elections in the European Union") for the [European Parliament](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Parliament "European Parliament").

Local administration in Greece recently underwent extensive reform in two phases: the first phase, implemented in 1997 and commonly called the [Kapodistrias Plan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kapodistrias_Plan "Kapodistrias Plan"), consolidated the country's numerous municipalities and communities down to approximately 1000. The second phase, initially called Kapodistrias II but eventually called the [Kallikratis Plan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kallikratis_Plan "Kallikratis Plan"), was implemented in 2010, further consolidated municipalities down to 370, and merged the country's 54 prefectures, which were disbanded in favour of the larger 13 regions. The Kallikratian municipalities were designed according to several guidelines; for example, each island (except [Crete](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crete "Crete")) was incorporated into a single municipality, while the majority of small towns were consolidated so as to have an average municipal population of 25,000.

### India

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: India")]

Main article: [Mayor (India)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor_(India) "Mayor (India)")

In [India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India "India"), the mayor is the first citizen of a city and the head of [municipal corporation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Municipal_corporation_(India) "Municipal corporation (India)") which is a local government of cities with a population over one million. They have a number of roles, both ceremonial and functional. In most Indian states mayors are elected indirectly among the [corporators](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Councillor "Councillor") (who are directly elected by the people of their respective [wards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ward_(electoral_subdivision) "Ward (electoral subdivision)")) of the municipal corporation, except in nine states: [Bihar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bihar "Bihar"), [Chhattisgarh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chhattisgarh "Chhattisgarh"), [Haryana](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haryana "Haryana"), [Jharkhand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jharkhand "Jharkhand"), [Madhya Pradesh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madhya_Pradesh "Madhya Pradesh"), [Odisha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Odisha "Odisha"), [Uttar Pradesh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uttar_Pradesh "Uttar Pradesh"), [Telangana](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telangana "Telangana") and [Uttarakhand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uttarakhand "Uttarakhand"), where mayors are elected directly by the public.

### Indonesia

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Indonesia")]

In [Indonesia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indonesia "Indonesia"), mayor ([Indonesian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indonesian_language "Indonesian language"): *wali kota*, formerly called *walikotamadya* and *walikota*) is a regional head of a city or town. A mayor has the same level as a [regent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regent "Regent") (*bupati*), head of a regency (*kabupaten*). A mayor has the duty and authority to lead the implementation of the policies established by the region along with the city council (*Dewan Perwakilan Rakyat Daerah Kota*, DPRD Kota; formerly called Tier 2-DPRD (*DPRD Tingkat II*)). A mayor is elected in a pair with a vice mayor through direct elections and is a political office. An exception is [Special Capital Region of Jakarta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jakarta "Jakarta"), where mayoralty is a civil-service career position with limited authority and is designated by [the governor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Governor_of_Jakarta "Governor of Jakarta"). Their regions are called [administration cities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jakarta#Administrative_divisions "Jakarta") (*kota administrasi*).

Before 1999, there were administrative cities (*kota administratif*, [[id]](https://id.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kota_administratif "id:Kota administratif")) which were headed by administrative mayors.

### Iran

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: Iran")]

In [Iran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iran "Iran"), the mayor is the executive manager of a city and is elected by the Islamic City Council. The mayor is elected for a four-year term.

### Ireland

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: Ireland")]

In the [Republic of Ireland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland "Republic of Ireland"), the head of a [borough](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Borough#Ireland "Borough") corporation was called "mayor" from the [Municipal Corporations (Ireland) Act 1840](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Municipal_Corporations_(Ireland)_Act_1840 "Municipal Corporations (Ireland) Act 1840") until boroughs were abolished by the [Local Government Reform Act 2014](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_Government_Reform_Act_2014 "Local Government Reform Act 2014"). [City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/City_status_in_Ireland "City status in Ireland") council chairs are "mayor" (or "lord mayor" in the cases [of Dublin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lord_Mayor_of_Dublin "Lord Mayor of Dublin") and [of Cork](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lord_Mayor_of_Cork "Lord Mayor of Cork")). The [Local Government Act 2001](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_Government_Act_2001 "Local Government Act 2001") allowed [county](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Counties_of_Ireland "Counties of Ireland") councils to style their chairperson as "mayor" and some do so. Since 2000 [there have been proposals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proposed_directly_elected_mayor_for_the_Dublin_Metropolitan_Area "Proposed directly elected mayor for the Dublin Metropolitan Area") for a directly elected mayor of the [Dublin Metropolitan Area](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dublin_Metropolitan_Area "Dublin Metropolitan Area"). The [2019 local elections](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Irish_local_elections "2019 Irish local elections") included plebiscites in three areas on directly elected mayors, of which that for [Mayor of Limerick](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor_of_Limerick "Mayor of Limerick") was passed, with the first direct election due as part of the [2024 local elections](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Irish_local_elections "2024 Irish local elections").[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor#cite_note-13)

### Italy

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section: Italy")]

Main article: [Metropolitan mayor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metropolitan_mayor "Metropolitan mayor")

In Italy, the mayor is called *sindaco*, or informally *primo cittadino* ('first citizen'). Every municipality ([Italian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_language "Italian language"): *comune*) has a mayor who represents the local government. The mayor is directly elected every five years by the inhabitants of the *[comune](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comune "Comune")*; the mayor cannot serve for more than two consecutive terms, except in municipalities of up to 5,000 inhabitants, those having a three consecutive terms limit.[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor#cite_note-14)

The mayor is a member of the City council, the legislative body which checks the mayor's policy guidelines and is able to enforce his resignation by a [motion of no confidence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_of_no_confidence "Motion of no confidence"), and is entitled to appoint and release the members of the executive body ([Italian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_language "Italian language"): *giunta*).

### Japan

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: Japan")]

Japan's [Local-Autonomy Law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_Autonomy_Law "Local Autonomy Law") of 1947 defines the structure of Japanese local governments, which were strengthened after World War II. It gives strong executive power to the mayor in local politics like [strong mayors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor-council_government#Executive_or_Strong_Mayor_Form "Mayor-council government") in large cities in the United States of America. The titles that are translated as *mayor* by the governments are those of the heads of [cities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cities_of_Japan "Cities of Japan") *shichō* (市長), [towns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Towns_of_Japan "Towns of Japan") *chōchō* (町長), [villages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Villages_of_Japan "Villages of Japan") *sonchō* (村長), and Tokyo's [special wards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special_wards_of_Tokyo "Special wards of Tokyo") *kuchō* (区長) (The head of the [Tokyo prefecture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tokyo "Tokyo") is the Governor (知事, *Chiji*)).

A mayor is elected every four years by direct popular votes held separately from the assembly. A mayor can be [recalled](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recall_election "Recall election") by a popular initiative but the [prefectural](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prefectures_of_Japan "Prefectures of Japan") and the national governments cannot remove a mayor from office. Towards the assembly the mayor prepares budgets, proposes local [acts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Act_of_Parliament "Act of Parliament") and may veto local acts approved by the assembly which can be overridden by two-thirds assembly support. A mayor can dissolve the assembly if the assembly passes a [motion of no confidence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_of_no_confidence "Motion of no confidence") or if the mayor thinks the assembly has no confidence in fact.

### Kazakhstan

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=24 "Edit section: Kazakhstan")]

Main article: [Akim](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Akim "Akim")

In Kazakhstan, the mayor is called *akim*, who is the head of an *akimat*, a municipal, district, or provincial government (*mayorat*), and serves as the presidential representative. *Akim**s* of provinces and cities are appointed to the post by the president on the advice of the prime minister. Meanwhile, the *akim**s* of other administrative and territorial units are appointed or elected to the post in an order defined by the president. The president may also dismiss *akim**s* from their posts. The *akims*' powers end upon the newly elected president of the republic taking office. Thus, the *akims* continue to fulfill their duties before the appointment of the corresponding *akim* by the President of Kazakhstan.

### Malaysia

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: Malaysia")]

See also: [Mayor of Kuala Lumpur](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor_of_Kuala_Lumpur "Mayor of Kuala Lumpur") and [Mayor of Penang Island](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor_of_Penang_Island "Mayor of Penang Island")

The mayor functions as the head of the local government of the cities in Malaysia. To date, there are [14 officially-recognised cities in the country](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Malaysia#Cities_of_Malaysia "List of cities in Malaysia").

In cities which lie within the jurisdiction of any one of the [13 Malaysian states](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/States_and_federal_territories_of_Malaysia "States and federal territories of Malaysia"), the mayor is appointed by the state government.[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor#cite_note-:0-15) [Kuala Lumpur](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kuala_Lumpur "Kuala Lumpur"), the country's capital, is a notable exception, as it forms part of the [Federal Territories](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Territories_(Malaysia) "Federal Territories (Malaysia)") which come under the purview of the [Malaysian federal government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_of_Malaysia "Government of Malaysia"), via the [Ministry of Federal Territories](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ministry_of_Federal_Territories_(Malaysia) "Ministry of Federal Territories (Malaysia)"). Thus, the mayor of Kuala Lumpur is selected by, and subordinate to, the [Minister of Federal Territories](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minister_of_Federal_Territories_(Malaysia) "Minister of Federal Territories (Malaysia)").[[16]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor#cite_note-16)

Following the [2018 general election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malaysian_general_election,_2018 "Malaysian general election, 2018"), which saw the country undergoing its first ever regime change, there have been calls to revive local government elections, which had been the practice in certain cities such as Kuala Lumpur, [George Town](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Town,_Penang "George Town, Penang"), [Ipoh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ipoh "Ipoh") and [Melaka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malacca_City "Malacca City") until their abolishment in 1965.[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor#cite_note-:0-15)[[17]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor#cite_note-17)[[18]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor#cite_note-18) The reinstatement of local government elections would lead to the mayoral position being elected, instead of being appointed as per the current system.

### Malta

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Malta")]

In Malta, the mayor ([Maltese](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maltese_language "Maltese language"): *sindku*) is the leader of the majority party in the [local council](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_councils_of_Malta "Local councils of Malta"). The members of the local councils are directly elected and collectively serve as a basic form of local government.

### Moldova

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section: Moldova")]

The mayor of the municipality in Moldova is elected for four years.[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor#cite_note-19) In [Chișinău](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chi%C8%99in%C4%83u "Chișinău"), the last mayoral elections[*[when?](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items "Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")*] had to be repeated three times because of the low rate of participation.[*[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*]

### Nepal

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=28 "Edit section: Nepal")]

Further information: [List of mayors of municipalities in Nepal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_mayors_of_municipalities_in_Nepal "List of mayors of municipalities in Nepal")

Mayors in Nepal are elected every five years in the [local elections](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elections_in_Nepal "Elections in Nepal"). They are very powerful in municipal government. The mayor is the highest-ranking official in a municipal government in Nepal.

### Netherlands

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=29 "Edit section: Netherlands")]

Main article: [Burgemeester](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burgemeester "Burgemeester")

In the [Netherlands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Netherlands "Netherlands"), the mayor ([Dutch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dutch_language "Dutch language"): *burgemeester*) is the leader of the college of mayor and aldermen (*[College van Burgemeester en Wethouders](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/College_van_Burgemeester_en_Wethouders "College van Burgemeester en Wethouders")*), the municipal executive. In the Netherlands, *burgemeester**s* are *de facto* appointed by the national [cabinet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cabinet_of_the_Netherlands "Cabinet of the Netherlands"), *de jure* by the [monarch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dutch_Monarchy "Dutch Monarchy"). Appointment is generally preceded by a selection procedure and nomination by the municipal council and king's commissioner (head of the provincial executive), and a nomination is only very rarely not followed by an appointment. Mayors preside over both the municipal executive and the legislative (*[gemeenteraad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gemeenteraad "Gemeenteraad")*), although they can vote in the former and not in the latter. The title is sometimes translated as [burgomaster](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burgomaster "Burgomaster"), to emphasise the appointed, rather than elected, nature of the office.

The appointment procedure was brought for discussion in the early 2000s (decade), as some of the political parties represented in parliament regarded the procedure as undemocratic. Generally, mayors in the Netherlands are selected from the established political parties, although since the late 2010s mayors without political affiliation have become more common.[[20]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor#cite_note-20) Alternatives proposed were direct election of the mayor by the people or official appointment by the municipal council (*gemeenteraad*). A constitutional change to allow for this failed to pass the [Senate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Senate_of_the_Netherlands "Senate of the Netherlands") in March 2005, but succeeded in 2018.

### New Zealand

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=30 "Edit section: New Zealand")]

Main article: [Mayors in New Zealand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayors_in_New_Zealand "Mayors in New Zealand")

Mayors in New Zealand are elected every three years in the [local body elections](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elections_in_New_Zealand "Elections in New Zealand").

### Pakistan

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=31 "Edit section: Pakistan")]

Further information: [Nazim](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nazim "Nazim")

In [Pakistan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pakistan "Pakistan"), a city is headed by the [district](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Districts_of_Pakistan "Districts of Pakistan") *nazim* (the word means 'administrator' in Urdu, but is sometimes translated as 'mayor') and assisted by the [*naib nazim*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naib_Nazim "Naib Nazim"), who is also speaker of the district council. The district *nazim* is elected by the *nazims* of [union councils](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Union_councils_of_Pakistan "Union councils of Pakistan"), union councillors and by [tehsil](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehsil "Tehsil") *nazims*, who themselves are elected directly by the votes of the local public. Council elections are held every four years.

### Philippines

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=32 "Edit section: Philippines")]

In the [Philippines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philippines "Philippines"), mayors ([Tagalog](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tagalog_language "Tagalog language"): *Punong Bayan / Punong Lungsod / Alkalde*) are the head of a [municipality or a city](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_cities_and_municipalities_in_the_Philippines "List of cities and municipalities in the Philippines"), with the vice mayor as the second-highest position in the city. They are elected every three years during the midterm and national elections, and they can serve up to three consecutive terms of office. As of September 2012[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit), there are 1,635 mayors in the Philippines.[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor#cite_note-21)

### Poland

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=33 "Edit section: Poland")]

See also: [List of cities and towns in Poland § Cities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Poland#Cities "List of cities and towns in Poland")

As of 30 April 2022, there are altogether 2477 municipalities ([gmina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gmina "Gmina")) in Poland, including 1513 rural gminas, while the remaining 968 ones contain cities and towns. Among them, 666 towns are part of an urban-rural gmina while 302 cities and towns are standalone as an urban gmina. The latter group includes 107 cities (governed by a *prezydent miasta*), including 66 [cities with powiat rights](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/City_with_powiat_rights "City with powiat rights"). 37 cities among the latter group are over 100,000, including 18 cities serving as a seat for [voivode](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voivode "Voivode") or [voivodeship sejmik](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voivodeship_sejmik "Voivodeship sejmik"), informally called voivodeship cities.

All municipalities in Poland including cities and towns are governed under the mandatory [mayor–council government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor%E2%80%93council_government "Mayor–council government") system. Executive power is vested in an official called one of the following:

* a city mayor (*prezydent miasta*)
* a town mayor (*burmistrz*)
* a *[wójt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/W%C3%B3jt "Wójt")* which is the equivalent office in a rural municipality (*[gmina wiejska](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gmina "Gmina")*)

They are elected by a [two-round](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two-round_system "Two-round system") [direct election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Direct_election "Direct election") for a five-year term concurrently with the five-year term of the [municipal council](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Municipal_council "Municipal council") and cannot serve in the latter or in any higher-level deliberative bodies: a [county council](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/County_council "County council"), a [voivodeship sejmik](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voivodeship_sejmik "Voivodeship sejmik"), the [Parliament of Poland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parliament_of_Poland "Parliament of Poland") or the [European Parliament](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Parliament "European Parliament"). Citizens with a criminal record cannot run for mayor, but only if sentenced for intentional criminal offence prosecuted [ex officio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ex_officio "Ex officio"). The [municipal/town/city council](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Municipal_council "Municipal council") is the legislative, budget-making and oversight body. Mayor is obliged to appoint his deputy. A town or city mayor may be scrutinized or denied funding for his/her projects by the council, but is not politically responsible to it and does not require its confidence to remain in office; therefore, [cohabitation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cohabitation_(government) "Cohabitation (government)") is not uncommon. A [recall referendum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recall_election "Recall election") may however be triggered through a petition supported by at least 1/10 of eligible voters, but the turnout in the recall referendum must be at least 3/5 of the number of people voting in the original election in order for the referendum to be valid and binding. A town/city mayor can also be dismissed by the [prime minister](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_minister "Prime minister") in case of persistent transgression of the law.

Town/city mayors manage the municipal estate, issue administrative decisions and minor regulations, and incur [liabilities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liability_(financial_accounting) "Liability (financial accounting)") within limits set by the municipal council. They prepare and present the planned budget to the municipal council, subject to its acceptation and amendments. After the municipal council votes to accept the budget, the town/city mayor is responsible for its realization. Town/city mayors are heads of the [town/city hall (office)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Town_hall "Town hall"), the [register office](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Register_office "Register office") (the town/city mayor may appoint deputies for these specific tasks), as well as the parent authority for all public [kindergartens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kindergarten "Kindergarten") and [elementary schools](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elementary_school "Elementary school") in the municipality. They are also personally responsible for the [emergency management](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emergency_management "Emergency management") and [civil defense](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civil_defense "Civil defense") in a municipality. A municipality itself is responsible among others for [public transport](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_transport "Public transport"), [water supply](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Water_supply "Water supply") and [treatment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Water_treatment "Water treatment"), and [waste management](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waste_management "Waste management"). A town/city mayor has the legal capacity to act as employer for all the officials of a town/city hall. Town/city mayors in Poland have wide administrative and staffing authority: the only municipal executive official that the town/city mayor cannot appoint or dismiss is a [city treasurer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/City_treasurer "City treasurer"), who is appointed by the town/city council. Although they do not have in Poland power to veto city council resolutions, their position is relatively strong and should be classified as a [mayor-council government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor-council_government "Mayor-council government").In a [city with powiat rights](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/City_with_powiat_rights "City with powiat rights"), the city mayor also has the powers and duties of a powiat executive board and a [starosta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Starosta "Starosta").

In addition, an office of quarter mayor (*burmistrz dzielnicy*) exists in the [auxiliary units of the city of Warsaw, called quarters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quarters_and_neighbourhoods_of_Warsaw "Quarters and neighbourhoods of Warsaw"). In spite of remaining an integral part of the city as an entity, the quarters have a degree of autonomy legally guaranteed through a form of an own local self-government exercising some powers devolved by law from the city. Each of the 18 city quarters has an own council (*rada dzielnicy*) which elects an executive board (*zarząd dzielnicy*) headed by a quarter mayor (*burmistrz dzielnicy*), the latter elected by the council among several candidates nominated by the city mayor of Warsaw among the council's members, as opposed to a town or a city mayor, both elected under direct suffrage.

### Portugal

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=34 "Edit section: Portugal")]

In [Portugal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portugal "Portugal") and many other Portuguese-speaking countries the mayor of a municipality is called the *Presidente da Câmara Municipal* ('[President of the Municipal Chamber](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_the_Municipal_Chamber "President of the Municipal Chamber")').

### Romania

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=35 "Edit section: Romania")]

In [Romania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Romania "Romania"), the mayor of a commune, town or city is called *primar*. The *primar* is elected for a period of four years. In carrying out their responsibilities they are assisted by an elected local council (*consiliu local*). [Bucharest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bucharest "Bucharest") has a general mayor (*primar general*) and six sector mayors (*primar de sector*), one for each [sector](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sectors_of_Bucharest "Sectors of Bucharest"). The responsibilities of the mayor and of the local council are defined by Law 215/2001 of the Romanian Parliament.[[22]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor#cite_note-22)

### Russia

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=36 "Edit section: Russia")]

In Russia, the Мэр, from French *maire* (transliteration: *mer* – not to be confused with the NATO [OF-3](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OF-3 "OF-3") rank Майор – English: *[major](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Major_(rank) "Major (rank)")*), is one of the possible titles of the head of the administration of a city or municipality. This title is equivalent to that of the head of a Russian rural district. Exceptionally, the *mer* of [Moscow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moscow "Moscow"), [Saint-Petersburg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saint-Petersburg "Saint-Petersburg") and [Sevastopol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sevastopol "Sevastopol") are equivalent to governors in Russia, since these three federal cities are Russian [federal subjects](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_subject "Federal subject").

Except for the aforementioned three large cities, the governance system of a Russian municipality (city, county, district or town) is subordinate to the representative council of the federation in which it is located. The *mer* is either directly elected in municipal elections (citywide referendum) or is elected by the members of the municipality's representative council. Election by council members is now more widespread because it better integrates with the Russian federal three-level vertical governance structure:

1. National government:
   1. President (executive)
   2. [Federal Assembly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Assembly_(Russia) "Federal Assembly (Russia)")
2. Federation governments:
   1. Heads of federation (commonly governors)
   2. Regional representative councils
3. Local governments:
   1. Heads of administration (who have the official title of *mer*, whether or not local law defines it as such)
   2. Local representative councils

The typical term of office of a *mer* in Russia is four years. The *mer**'s* office administers all municipal services, public property, police and fire protection, and most public agencies, and enforces all local and state laws within a city or town.

According to Medialogy,[[23]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor#cite_note-23) the *mer* of [Novosibirsk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novosibirsk "Novosibirsk"), Anatoly Lokot', is mentioned in the media more than any other Russian mayor. The *mer* of [Kazan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kazan "Kazan"), Il'sur Metshin, is the most popular in Russia, scoring 76 out of 100, according to the Russian People's Rating of *Mer**s*.[[24]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor#cite_note-24)

The status of the post in Sevastopol is not legally recognized outside of the [Russian Federation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_Federation "Russian Federation").

### Serbia

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=37 "Edit section: Serbia")]

In [Serbia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serbia "Serbia"), the mayor is the head of the city or a town. The mayor acts on behalf of the city, and performs an executive function. The position of the mayor of [Belgrade](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belgrade "Belgrade") is important as the capital city is the most important hub of economics, culture and science in [Serbia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serbia "Serbia"). Furthermore, the post of the mayor of Belgrade is the third most important position in the government after the [prime minister](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Serbia "Prime Minister of Serbia") and [president](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_Serbia "President of Serbia"). The *Local Administration Act of 2007* establishes a mayor-council system for all municipalities, except city municipalities that are part of a city. The title of the mayor varies: the formal title of municipality heads is the *President of Municipality* (*[Serbian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serbian_language "Serbian language"): председник општине, [romanized](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Romanization_of_Serbian "Romanization of Serbian"): *predsednik opštine**) while cities are headed by mayors (*[Serbian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serbian_language "Serbian language"): градоначелник, [romanized](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Romanization_of_Serbian "Romanization of Serbian"): *gradonačelnik**); both are, however, called *gradonačelnik* in everyday parlance. The mayor is elected indirectly by the city council for a term of 4 years, without a term limit; previously, from 1990 to 2006 mayors were elected directly by voters in local elections alongside the municipal council.

### Spain and Hispanic America

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=38 "Edit section: Spain and Hispanic America")]

Main article: [Alcalde](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alcalde "Alcalde")

*Alcalde* is the most common Spanish term for the mayor of a town or city. It is derived from the [Arabic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arabic_language "Arabic language"): *[al-qaḍi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qadi "Qadi")* (قاضي), i.e., 'the ([Sharia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sharia "Sharia")) judge', who often had administrative, as well as judicial, functions. Although the [Castilian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crown_of_Castile "Crown of Castile") *alcalde* and the [Andalusian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Al-Andalus "Al-Andalus") *qaḍi* had slightly different attributes (the *qaḍi* oversaw an entire province, the *alcalde* only a municipality; the former was appointed by the ruler of the state but the latter was elected by the [municipal council](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cabildo_(council) "Cabildo (council)")), the adoption of this term reflects how much Muslim society in the [Iberian Peninsula](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula "Iberian Peninsula") influenced the Christian one in the early phases of the *[Reconquista](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reconquista "Reconquista")*. As Spanish Christians took over an increasing part of the Peninsula, they adapted the Muslim systems and terminology for their own use.

Today, it refers to the executive head of a municipal or local government, who usually does not have judicial functions. The word *[intendente](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intendant "Intendant")* is used in [Argentina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argentina "Argentina") and [Paraguay](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paraguay "Paraguay") for the office that is analogous to a mayor.

In [*municipios*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Municipio "Municipio") and larger cities in [Mexico](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mexico "Mexico"), the chief executive is known as both *alcalde* or as *presidente municipal* ('municipal president'), with the latter being more widely used.

### Sweden

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=39 "Edit section: Sweden")]

The Swedish title *borgmästare* ([burgomaster](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burgomaster "Burgomaster")) was abolished in the court reform of 1971 when also the [towns of Sweden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stad_(Sweden) "Stad (Sweden)") were officially abolished.

### Switzerland

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=40 "Edit section: Switzerland")]

The function and title for mayor vary from one canton to another. Generally, the mayor presides over an executive council of several members governing a [municipality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Municipalities_of_Switzerland "Municipalities of Switzerland").

The title is:

* In Italian: *sindaco* ([Ticino](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ticino "Ticino")), *podestà* ([Grigioni](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grigioni "Grigioni"))
* In French: *maire* ([Geneva](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canton_of_Geneva "Canton of Geneva"), [Jura](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canton_of_Jura "Canton of Jura"), [Bern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canton_of_Bern "Canton of Bern")), *syndic* ([Vaud](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vaud "Vaud"), [Fribourg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canton_of_Fribourg "Canton of Fribourg")), *président du conseil municipal* ([Valais](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Valais "Valais")), *président du conseil communal* ([Neuchâtel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canton_of_Neuch%C3%A2tel "Canton of Neuchâtel"))
* In German: e.g. *Stadtpräsident*, *Stadtammann*, *Gemeindepräsident*, *Gemeindeammann*

### Taiwan

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=41 "Edit section: Taiwan")]

In the [Republic of China](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republic_of_China "Republic of China") in Taiwan the mayor is the head of the city's government and its city's council, which is in charge of legislative affairs. The mayor and city council are elected separately by the city's residents.

### Turkey

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=42 "Edit section: Turkey")]

Mayors ([Turkish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turkish_language "Turkish language"): *belediye başkanı*) in Turkey are elected by popular vote for five years alongside the municipal council. As a rule, there are municipalities in all province centers and district centers as well as towns ([Turkish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turkish_language "Turkish language"): *belde*) which are actually villages with a population in excess of 2000. However, beginning by 1983, a new level of municipality was introduced in the Turkish administrative system. In big cities, metropolitan municipalities ([Turkish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turkish_language "Turkish language"): *Büyükşehir belediyesi*) are established. (See [metropolitan municipalities in Turkey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metropolitan_municipalities_in_Turkey "Metropolitan municipalities in Turkey")) In a metropolitan municipality there may be several district municipalities (hence mayors). Mayors are elected in [local elections.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elections_in_Turkey "Elections in Turkey")

### Ukraine

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mayor&action=edit&section=43 "Edit section: Ukraine")]

In [Ukraine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ukraine "Ukraine") the title "head of the city" ([Ukrainian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ukrainian_language "Ukrainian language"): міскй голова, [romanized](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Romanization_of_Ukrainian "Romanization of Ukrainian"): *misky holova*; unofficially the foreign adaptation [Ukrainian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ukrainian_language "Ukrainian language"): мер, [romanized](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Romanization_of_Ukrainian "Romanization of Ukrainian"): *mer* also is present) was introduced in 1999. Since then, the post is elected by all residents of the city.
